The Prime Minister said that, now that the negotiations forour accession to the European Economic Community (E.E.C.) had come to an end, it would be necessary for the Government tore-examine their economic policy and to respond constructively tothe many proposals which would henceforward be pressed on themfor action to offset the effects of our failure to join the Community.Our main objectives should be to strengthen relations with theCommonwealth, the European Free Trade Association and the member countries of the E.E.C., other than France, and to work for greater freedom in international trade.In discussion the following points were made:(a) There would be strong pressure for new Commonwealthtrading arrangements, based on the mistaken belief that theCommonwealth could be treated as a single economic entity. Itwould be unwise to appear merely to reject such initiatives. But,while our attitude towards the rest of the Commonwealth should remain sympathetic and co-operative, we should recognise that no useful results could be expected from a Commonwealth conferenceand that the possibility of enlarging Commonwealth trade would best be explored by bilateral negotiation with individual member countries. The Governments of Australia and New Zealand mightbe prepared to accept this view publicly, particularly in relation tothe discussions which would shortly have to be undertaken for the renewal of our trade agreement with Australia. To commit ourselves in those discussions to importing large quantities of Australian wheat for a further period while accepting the continuance of Australiandiscrimination against some of our more important industries wouldbe inconsistent with the realistic approach to economic problems which we must advocate if we were to succeed in promoting greater freedom in international trade.(b) The same considerations would be relevant in dealing withthe pressure which would now develop for a greater degree ofprotection against certain classes of import from Europe. It couldbe argued that protection should be reduced, rather than increased,if the economy was to be made more keenly competitive. Our policyin this regard would have to be settled in the context of theforthcoming negotiations under the General Agreement on tariffs and Trade.(c) There was still some expectation that negotiations for our entry into the E.E.C. might be resumed in a few months' time. Solong as this uncertainty persisted industrialists would continue tohesitate to take major decisions on manufacturing and investmentpolicy. In view of the political desirability of avoiding any actionwhich could be interpreted as a final break with Europe it might beimpossible to remove this uncertainty altogether; but the Govern-ment should give industry as clear a lead as possible.The Cabinet Took note that the Prime Minister, in consultation with theMinisters chiefly concerned, would give further considera-tion to the Governments economic policy in the light of the breakdown of the negotiations for the accession of theUnited Kingdom to the European Economic Community.C.C. 9 (63)Parliament 1. In these circumstances our efforts mustbe directed to restraining the Indonesian Government by all possible means.In discussion the following points were made:(a) There was at present no ban on strategic exports from theUnited Kingdom to Indonesia. Continuance of such exports, whichwere valuable to this country, might not greatly affect the situationin the Borneo Territories, where the main danger arose from guerillaactivity. But the policy should be kept under careful review, withparticular regard to the attitude of the United States Government tothe export of American arms to Indonesia.(b) The Philippine Government might seek to bring the situationin Borneo before the United Nations. Any such development wouldbe unwelcome, since it would tend to delay the establishment of greater Malaysia.The Cabinet (1) Took note of the Foreign Secretary's statement.Shipping 3. The principal aim of Saudi Arabian policy was tosecure the withdrawal of Egyptian forces from the Yemen; and,since this aim was believed to be shared by Marshal Sallal, thePresident of the Republican Government, there was some prospect that United Nations efforts to mediate would bring about the cessation of Saudi Arabian activity and a phased withdrawal of egyptian forces.
